according to the meanesse of the writing, but the candor of my mind,-
which I am assurd of, and for the future receive and register mee-

The Præface to the Reader.
Candid Reader!
It is a truth denyd by none that man in his composition
repræsents a compendium of the universe, and is destinated to live three kinds
of life, namely a vegetable, in his mothers wombe, where indeed hee growes-
and is encreased like a plant; a sensible, to witt in this world, where for the
most part hee is led by the Senses, as all other animalls, from which hee-
differs, in beginning to exercise the understanding, though imperfectly; and
lastly an intelligible, in the other world with God, and the Intelligences,
or good Angells assistent to him; in this life, the nearer a man comes to the
divine nature, the more doth hee rejoyce and is delighted in searching out-
things subtill wonderfull and rare, by the understanding: and on the contrary,
the more a man declines and degenerates to a bestiall kind, the lesse is hee-
affected with them, and is bound to a more corporeall sense.
X Wee see examples of either, that some, namely the more learned
are adorned with those arts and sciences, but very many addicted to these,
that is to say the pleasures of the body, lust, gluttony, externall pomp, Now to instruct-
and perfect the understanding God hath hidden infinite secrets in nature,-
which are forc'd out ofby innumerable arts and Sciences, as fire out of a flint,-
and transferrd to use: amongst these Chymicall secrets are not the mea
nest, but next to the indagation of divine things, the principall and most-
pretious of all, not to be investigated by circumforaneous impostors, and-
pseudochymicall drones (who in these things are asini ad Lyram, because-
alltogether strangers to all good learning and intention) but by more lofty
witts, generously educated, and borne to greater things, they being very sub
till, concise, sacred, rare, and abstruse, and therefore to be comprehended
by the understanding sooner than by sense, rather by profound contem
the præface to the Reader.
plation upon the reading of authors, and comparing them together, and-
with the works of nature, than sensitive operation, or manuall experi
mentation, which is blind without prævious theory: next after such intellec
tuall sciences as these are reckoned those which treat of a visible and au
dible object, as are Opticks, or perspectives, and Picture, which is by some
Poets called mute, as this on the contrary a speaking picture, as allso Mu
sicke, whether vocall, or instrumentall: herein the ancient Philosophers-
did soe exercise themselves, that hee was reputed unlearned, and forcd
to sing to the Myrtle, who refused the Harp in festivalls, as is declared of
Themistocles: in Musicke was Socrates instructed, and Plato himselfe, who
concluded him not harmoniously compounded, that delighted not in Musicall
harmony: Pythagoras was very famous in the same, who is sayd to have used
the symphony of musicke morning, and evening to compose the minds of
his disciples: for this is a peculiar virtue of Musicke, to quicken or refresh the
affections by the different musicall measures: Soe the Phrygian tune was-
by the Græks termed warrlike, because it was sung in warre, and upon en
gagement, and had a singular virtue in stirring up the Spirits of the-
Soldiers; instead of which the Jonicke is sometimes used for the same pur
pose, which was formerly esteemed amatory (as the Phrygian is sometimesnow re
puted) from which wee gather tunds changd one with another: it is sayd that
Timothy Milese used the Phrygian to make Alexander the great more-
Spritefull and couragious in warlike affaires, which Cicero takes notice of-
de legibus, but Terpander Lesbius of the Jonicke; who being sent for by-
the Lacedæmonians, seditious then raging among them, did by the sweet
nesse of singing soe titillate and affect their minds, that they returned-
into freindship, and desisted from sedition: upon which consideration the
Lesbian singers were allwayes præferrd in the judgment of the Spartans:-
Fabius sayth thus of Musicke: Musicke is an honest and pleasant recrea
tion most proper for generous witts: that therefore wee might have these-
three objects of the more spirituall senses, namely seing and hearing, as-
allso the understanding itselfe, as it were in one view and embrace, and
insinuate all at once into mens mends for the better understanding thereof,
behold wee have joyned the Opticke together with Musicke, and sense-
with the understanding, that is, things rare to be seen and heard of with
Chymicall emblems, which are peculiar to this Science: for all other arts,
if they represent emblems of manners, or other things, than of the secrets
of nature, this seems different from their scope and end, they being-
willing and requisite to be understood by all men; Chymy not soe,-
which as a chast virgin ought to be seen through a veile, and as Diana,
not without a garment of various colours, for reasons elswhere expres
sed: I say, these foure emblematicall, feigned, poeticall and allegoricall, pit
ted notions, graved in Venus or Copper, not without Venus or eleganty; most
abstruse Chymicall things, and lastly most rare Musicall things to be enu
cleated by the understanding, you have alltogether in one booke, and may
as designed apply them to your owne use, which if it be more intel
the præface to the Reader.
lectuall, than sensuall, the more profitable and delightfull will it be in time:
but if it be first in bondage to the sense, there is noe doubt but there will-
be a passage from the sense to the understanding as by a doore: for nothing is
sayd to be in the understanding, which had not admission by some sense,-
the understanding of a mannew borne being supposd as a smooth table,-
wherein nothing is as yet written, but any thing may be written by the-
helpe of sense, as a Style: and it is comonly sayd, there is noe desire of a
thing unknowne, because the senses being inquisitors and messengers must
first convey, and as warders the instruments of a citty watching at the gates (their organs) of cittythereof
informe and impart everything that is to be knowne, to the understanding,
as the dictator and arbiter. As to the reason of engraving these Emblems,
lest even they may seem monstrous and incongruous to you, I will add a few
things: Atalanta is renowned by the Poets for speed in running, in which exercise
shee surpassed all her suitors, and therefore, the reward of victory being
propounded, death ensued to these beingthat were overrunne by the Virgin, till Shee
herselfe was overcome by Hippomenes, a youth morevery hardy and circumspect,
casting three golden apples at three severall times in her way, which taking up,
Shee was in the meane time outgone by him, being now near and touching-
the goale: as this Atalanta runns, soe one Musicall note allwayes runns before
another as Hippomenes, and the other followes: yet they are established and
confirmed in a third, which is single and of one validity as a golden apple:
This same virgin is merely Chymicall, namely Philosophicall Mercury-
fixed in flight and restrained by the golden Sulphur, which if a man-
know how to make stand, hee will have that Spouse which hee desires, if-
not, destruction and ruine of his affaires: From Hippomenes and Atalanta
lying together in the temple of the mother of the Gods, that is, a vessell,-
are Lyons produced, or they acquire a red colour: This virgin allso obtaind
a victory before men, killing a certaine boar of notable bignesse, for which
Shee was rewarded by Meleager: Striking a rocke at Slethæus the temple
of Æsculapius Shee brought forth water, whichwhereof being thirsty, Shee dranke:
which things being truely allegoricall and emblematicall, and noe way
historicall, I was willing that this intellectual emblematicall treatise-
Should indigitate and take notice of them in commemoration of this noble
Heroesse, especially the apples cast before her being taken out of the-
Hesperian gardens, and administred to Hippomenes by Venus, the Goddesse
of favour and sweetnesse: in those Musicall measures or flights you see-
this observed, that every disticke being conveniently adapted to those three
voyces may be expressd in singing, in which soe many varietyes of flights
being accomodated to one single voyce, every wise and intelligent man will
allso thinke well of this kind of emblematicall figuration in them, as-
allso the adaptation in the disticks to every voyce: for if some Merchants
doe esteeme and buy an artifice of picture with a great summe of money,
where the eyes alone are deceived, they judging it very near to nature,-
why should not the learned have these figures in good estimation-
the præface to the Reader.
which are soe usefull and serviceable both to the understanding and
many of the senses, that great utility besides delight and recreation-
may be expected from them? Farewell. . . . . . .
